Go Weekly

Interactive Release Notes for Go 1.23 â€” If you find traditional release notes hard going, this interactive alternative with inline executable code snippets might help you get a grip on some of 1.23's changes before the final release nextÂ month.

Anton Zhiyanov

ğŸ’¡ While we're on the topic.. Go 1.23 Release Candidate 2 has beenÂ released.

First Impressions of Go 1.23's Range-over-Func Feature â€” When the author read Goâ€™s newest iteration proposal, he felt a bit intimidated, but decided to kick the tires and share his experiences. Now? He lovesÂ it!

Jonathan Hall

Run GitHub Actions Up to 2x Faster at Half theÂ Cost â€” Blacksmith runs your GitHub Actions substantially faster by running them on modern gaming CPUs. Integrating Blacksmith is a one-line code change. 100+ companies like GitBook, Superblocks, and Slope use Blacksmith to help developers merge codeÂ faster.

Blacksmith sponsor

Hash-Based Bisect Debugging in Compilers and Runtimes â€” If youâ€™ve ever had to debug a large set of changes as part of an unfamiliar code base, this approach may feel like magic, so much so that Russ and others have created a CLI (bisect) to make the task easier. The explanation of using binary search, git bisect, and the bisect CLI here are veryÂ informative.

Russ Cox

ï£¿Â How I Build Simple Mac Apps using Go â€” The creator of DarwinKit, a set of native Apple APIs for Go, shows off how he uses it to create basic MacÂ apps.

Jeff Lindsay

Live Website Updates with Go, SSE, and HTMX â€” Showing real-time updates on a site may steer you toward WebSockets, but going the SSE (Server-Sent Events) route with HTMX provides a solid and simpler experience.

MiÅ‚osz SmÃ³Å‚ka

Safeguarding Changes using the Plan-Execute Pattern â€” A pattern used by tools like Terraform where a preview of changes is shown before applying them. Tom creates a simple example of importing data into a database while highlighting new, changed, and removedÂ entities.

Tom Nick

ğŸ“„ gRPC Over HTTP/3 â€“ Complete with practical examples inÂ Go. Kevin McDonald

ğŸ“„ Calling Go Functions from C++ Matteo / xnacly

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

Notify 1.0: Send Notifications to Various Messaging Services â€” Supports about thirty different services including Discord, AWS SES and SNS, Microsoft Teams, Slack, andÂ Telegram.

Niko KÃ¶ser

Boost Your Go App Security with FusionAuth: Try Our ExampleÂ SDKs â€” Explore real-world example apps to integrate secure user management into your GoÂ projects.

FusionAuth sponsor

ğŸ”’Â govulncheck 1.1: Find Vulnerable Dependencies in Your GoÂ Code â€” Govulncheck uses static analysis on your code, along with the Go Vulnerability Database, to report relevant known vulnerabilities to you. Thereâ€™s an official tutorial on how to use itÂ too.

Julie Qiu (Go Security Team)

LinDB: A Go-Powered Time Series Database System â€” Joining a long line of Go-powered database systems comes LinDB, a new performance and availability-focused time-series database that can be accessed via a REST API. GitHubÂ repo.

Lin Labs Inc.

Kratos 2.8: A Go Framework for Cloud-Based Microservices â€” A â€œmicroservice-oriented governance frameworkâ€ built aroundÂ HTTP/gRPC.

Kratos

  • go-redis 9.6 â€“ Redis clientÂ library. v9.6 adds support for hash field expiration commands as introduced in RedisÂ 7.4.

  • go-resiliency 1.7 â€“ Resiliency patterns forÂ Go. Circuit-breaker, deadlineÂ &Â more.

  • Permify 0.10 â€“ Google Zanzibar-inspiredÂ authorization.

  • Buf 1.35 â€“ CLI tool for working with ProtocolÂ Buffers.

  • Delve 1.23 â€“ Popular debugging tool for GoÂ code.

item.title: ã€The GopherCon UK experienceã€‘è‹±å›½ GopherCon ä½“éªŒ
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹519 â€” August 20, 2024

UnsubÂ Â |Â Â WebÂ Version

ğŸ–ï¸ If you missed last week's issue, don't worry - you didn't. I took a week off for a summer break, but now we're back ;-) Thanks to everyone who sent in links for us to checkÂ out.
__
Peter Cooper, your editor

Go Weekly

Go 1.23 Released â€” Weâ€™ve been hearing about (and linking to) 1.23 for weeks in its various pre-release guises, but now it's here. You could call 1.23 a 'major minor' release, as it's mostly a gentle step forward but with some new features, like for range iteration and tooling additions (including the now opt-in telemetry system). Head to the official release notes for all theÂ details.

The Go Team

ğŸ’¡ For a more practical look at language improvements, don't forget Anton Zhiyanov's fantastic interactive release notes andÂ examples.

Structs are Copied on Assignment (and Other Things About Go I'd Missed) â€” This gotcha likely catches many new-to-intermediate gophers, along with the other issues Julia also mentions. By the way, these are based on a few of the 100 Go Mistakes and How to Avoid Them site andÂ book.

Julia Evans

A Complete Introduction to Containers â€” Join Brian Holt for this extensive video course covering the now industry standard approach for developing and deploying apps. You'll learn about core container technology, Docker Images, multi-container projects, and muchÂ more.

Frontend Masters sponsor

â–¶Â Â 12 Talks from GopherCon UK 2024 â€” GopherCon UK took place just a few days ago, but you can already enjoy a variety of talks including Matt Boyle on debugging Go apps, JesuÌs Espino digging into Goâ€™s runtime, Beth Anderson on AI, and Googleâ€™s Michael Pratt look at profile guidedÂ optimization. We'll feature more talks in future issues as we watch them, as there's a lot of gold inÂ here.

GopherCon UK

ğŸ’¡ If you want to get more of a feel for what the event was like, Jamie Tanna did a write up of the GopherCon UK 2024 experience.

HTTP/1.0 From Scratch â€” We recently featured Kevinâ€™s HTTP/0.9 From Scratch, a first step into reimplementing the basics of HTTP, step by step, in Go. Now we get to fast forward five years to 1996 and HTTP/1.0 which introduced things like the POST action, status codes, and contentÂ negotiation.

Kevin McDonald

'An Unordered List of Things I Miss in Go' â€” A solid list with some doable and not-so-doable items. On the doable side, there are ordered maps and default arguments. On the not-so-doable, null/nilability is a long-time contentious subject that likely would break backwardÂ compatibility.

kokada

Go Maps Explained: How Key-Value Pairs Are Actually Stored â€” A comprehensive, illustrated tutorial to how things are represented under theÂ hood.

Phuong Le

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

go-vcr 4.0: Record and Replay Your HTTP Interactions â€” Record and replay API interactions for faster, deterministic testing of potentially flaky endpoints â€“ hereâ€™s the v4.0 changelog. (If youâ€™ve used Ruby, you might recognize its inspiration: the popular VCRÂ library.)

Marin Atanasov Nikolov

GoNB: A Go Notebook Kernel for Jupyter â€” Notebooks make it easy to do literate programming where you see results immediately like a REPL but with persistence and control over the source code. Common in Python, GoNB brings Go into the picture too. The latest release adds Jupytext support.

Jan Pfeifer

FusionAuth. Auth Built for Devs, by Devs â€” Choose self-hosting or cloud, scale from 10 to 10 million users, and enjoy unlimited IDPs. Trusted by industry leaders with 10M+Â downloads.

FusionAuth sponsor

Pie 2.9: A Utility Library for Dealing with Slices â€” Ways to work with slices with a focus on type safety, performance and immutability. Now with a a new UniqueStable operation.

Elliot Chance

Lo: A Lodash-Style Library for Go 1.18+ â€” Inspired by JavaScriptâ€™s Lodash and brings similar utility methods for working with slices, maps, andÂ more.

Samuel Berthe

kubetrim: Trim Your KUBECONFIG Automatically â€” Takes your kubeconfig and trims out all the old / unused clusters andÂ contexts.

Alex Ellis

  • Bubble Tea 0.27 â€“ The powerful, popular TUI framework adds support for programmatically suspending and resumingÂ programs.

  • GoLand 2024.2 â€“ The latest release of JetBrains' popular commercial GoÂ IDE.

  • Pion TURN 4.0 â€“ Toolkit for building TURN clients andÂ servers.

  • GoReleaser 2.2 â€“ Build/release binaries for multipleÂ platforms.

  • wazero 1.8 â€“ Zero dependency WebAssembly runtime forÂ Go.

  • NATS.go 1.37 â€“ Go client for the NATS messagingÂ system.

  • gofumpt 0.7 â€“ A stricter gofmt.

ã€

#â€‹517 â€” July 30, 2024

UnsubÂ Â |Â Â WebÂ Version

Go Weekly

Cogent Core: A New GUI Framework for Go â€” A new GUI framework with a â€œcode once and run everywhereâ€ promise for multiple platforms. It aims to be simpler to use than Gio and more powerful than Fyne. Curiously, Cogentâ€™s web site itself is built in the framework and compiled to WASM to work on the Web. Thereâ€™s also â–¶ï¸Â a quick screencast pitching you on theÂ framework.

Kai O'Reilly and Randy O'Reilly

Go Features by Version (or What's in Which Go) â€” A list of features and the versions in which they first appeared. Proof, if any were needed, that the progress made to Go isn't slowing down. (And if you want to get up to speed with Go 1.23, here are the notes forÂ you.)

Anton Zhiyanov

Render is Your Fastest Path to Production â€” Whatever your stack you can build, deploy quickly, update and confidently scale your apps with ease, from the first to the billionth user. Start building with Render for free â€” the modern cloud forÂ devs.

Render sponsor

Build Your Own SMTP Server in Go â€” The actual code here isnâ€™t low level, but it's a good practical guide to some of the technologies around sending e-mail, like SMTP, DKIM, and SPF. The go-smtp library ultimately does the heavyÂ lifting.

Alexis Bouchez

Whatâ€™s New in Go 1.23: Iterators and reflect.Value.Seq â€” Carlana explains four of the functions around generic custom iteration that she proposed, comparing the new code to something she wrote ten(!) years ago using channels. If 2022 was all about generics, is 2024 the year ofÂ iterators?

Carlana Johnson

Learn Go with Tests: A Refactoring Checklist â€” The popular Learn Go with Tests guide gains a new chapter that gets you thinking about refactoring, when it makes sense to do it, and some of the basicÂ techniques.

Chris James

The Union of Finite Automata, Explained â€” Tim found existing explanations to be overly academic, so set out to explain the concept with a littleÂ Go.

Tim Bray

Merge Go Code 10x Faster at Quality with AI-Driven CodeÂ Reviews â€” AI-first pull request reviewer that offers context-aware, line-by-line feedback and smart chat. Get a 7-day free trial. Free for OSSÂ projects.

CodeRabbit sponsor

ğŸ“„ Parsing Protobuf Definitions with Tree-sitter â€“ If you need to go a few steps beyond what protoc canÂ do. Karl Matthias

ğŸ“„ Highlights from Git 2.46 Taylor Blau (GitHub)

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

Ollama 0.3: Quickly Run Large Language Models â€” Ollama is an increasingly significant Go-powered tool in the LLM world (that uses llama.cpp behind the scenes) that makes it easy to run large language models. Recent releases have added concurrency, Llama 3.1 support, and, now, toolÂ calling.

Ollama Team

betteralign 0.5: Make Your Programs Use Less Memory.. Maybe â€” A tool to detect structs that could use less memory. Itâ€™s a fork of Goâ€™s fieldalignment tool that skips generated or test files, skips specially marked structs or those with anonymous fields, doesnâ€™t drop comments, and similar DXÂ enhancements.

Dinko Korunic

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

ğŸš¨Prevent data breaches before they happen! Secure your Go app on AWS with LocalOpsâ€™ proven AWS security checklist. Download now and protect your data instantly!

Boost your PostgreSQL skills with Redgateâ€™s 101 webinar series of easy-to-follow, expert hosted sessions. Itâ€™s PostgreSQL, simplified.

âš™ï¸ Zeppelin â€“ A Go-powered Minecraft 1.21 server. â€œWhy?â€ asks the README. â€œWhy not,â€ comes theÂ reply. Various Contributors

âš™ï¸ Reed-Solomon â€“ Fast Reed-Solomon erasureÂ coding. Klaus Post

âš™ï¸ Circumflex â€“ A terminal UI for Hacker News. Ben Sadeh

  • FerretDB 1.23 â€“ It's like MongoDB, but on top of Postgres orÂ SQLite.

  • go-yaml 1.12.0 â€“ YAML processing for Go with moreÂ features.

  • Baur 5.0 â€“ Go-powered incremental task runner forÂ monorepos.

  • eBPF 0.16 â€“ Pure-Go library to work with eBPFÂ programs.

  • Goa 3.18 â€“ DSL for buildingÂ microservices.

ğŸ And one for fun..

Editor: A Source Code Editor in Pure Go â€” Curiously billing itself as a â€œsimple but advanced source code editorâ€, it works on Linux, Windows and macOS (under X server) and certainly has that old school Unix vibe goingÂ on. Clearly a serious labor of love after some seven years ofÂ development.

Jorge Miguel Pinto

ã€

#â€‹518 â€” August 6, 2024

UnsubÂ Â |Â Â WebÂ Version

ğŸ–ï¸ Hi! We're taking next week off for a brief summer break. We'll be back with our next issue on August 20. Also, if possible, can you click an item or two? We're going to be doing some 'list cleaning' soon and it's helpful to know if you're still keen to receive the newsletterÂ â€“ thanks!Â :-)
__
Peter Cooper, your editor

Go Weekly

Russ Cox Steps Down as Tech Lead of Go â€” Russ has been instrumental in many of Goâ€™s developments having led the project for 12 years, but itâ€™s time for a change with Austin Clements taking his position.
